subtitle: [Music]
New Thinking Allowed. Conversations on the
leading edge
of knowledge and discovery with
parapsychologist
Jeffrey Mishlove.
Hello, and welcome. I'm Jeffrey Mishlove.
Today, I'd like to talk about
the secret of the Rainbow Yin Yang.
It's the logo of the New Thinking Allowed
series. It's
one of the rare works of art that I've
created in my life.
I first created it over 40
years ago, and I've been working with it
ever since.
I was walking down Lake Street in San
Francisco at the time, and the idea just
popped into
my mind. Subsequently, I created
many versions using airbrush, using
computer
graphics, and eventually, the animated
version that you're looking at right now.
I actually own the copyright on
over 800 different variations
of the Rainbow Yin Yang.
But why? What does it signify?
There is actually a lot of deep meaning in the image.
Back in the days when I was lecturing at
the Philosophical
Research Society in Los Angeles, we had
an art exhibit of
some six giant-size Rainbow
Yin Yang images that were on display in
the auditorium, and I actually gave a
series of six lectures on the
metaphysical, symbolic, esoteric meaning
of the Yin Yang symbol and the Rainbow
Yin Yang, in particular.
Sometimes I jokingly say that it's the
first major improvement on the Yin Yang
in some 3,000 years.
One of the first things you'll notice when you look at the
animated image, of course, is
that it never stays the same. The colors
are always
changing, and actually, if you look more
closely, you see the eye
reflects the fish, I'll call it, the fish, the
image on the opposite side. So
the first lesson of the Yin Yang, of any
Yin Yang
image, is that everything contains
within it
the seed of its own opposite. That's an
incredibly profound insight and in some of
the interviews on this
program, it's been illustrated. Now, I
know a lot of people don't enjoy it when I
talk about
politics, because you may disagree with
my political perspective
or what you think my political
perspective is.
I did an interview with Glenn Aparicio
Parry, a series of four
interviews on Making America Sacred
Again, dealing with the dance of the
opposites in American politics, and unity
and diversity in American politics.
One thing we've seen quite dramatically,
for example, is that the Democratic Party
in American politics was once really the
conservative,
racist party, the pro-slavery
party in American politics. The
Republican Party
was the anti-slavery
party. And things have pretty much
reversed now. The Democrats are
the ones who fostered the
Civil Rights Movement. The Republicans
are the ones who are
trying to slow down civil rights
these days. So things reverse themselves
over time. This is a very important
dynamic
in human culture. It seems to me that,
whatever position
you take or I take, whether we are
Democrats or Communists or
fascists or upwingers or down-
wingers or cynics or anarchists
or conspiracy theorists or
skeptics, sooner or later,
those positions change because
embodied within them, essentially the
seed of their own opposite is
implicit in the position itself.
Now, you've heard me sometimes say,
in fact, in particular in my monologue
on nonduality,
I embrace the whole. I embrace everything,
the whole universe.
In the act of embracing the universe
there are no opposites any longer,
there's no duality
any longer. My friend, Russell Targ,
loves the Rainbow Yin Yang pins that are
incidentally available
on our website.
There'll be a link,
if you're interested in acquiring a
Rainbow Yin Yang pin, in the description
under this video. He says it's a
symbol of nonduality,
and why, it seems like, if anything
it's a symbol of
duality. But actually, if you look at
it carefully,
symbolically, it shows that the
duality itself
is only partially true. It's true at one
level. For sure, we live in a world of
duality, by which I mean
we live in a world of good and evil, of
right and wrong, of black and white.
But actually, they merge with each other.
If there was a world of black and white,
there would be no gray.
In a world of color there would be
no spectrum.
Everything blends, every color blends
into the next one.
I bring this up because
I often hear from
viewers who are convinced that there is
some evil in the world and they've got to
fight that evil.
It's interesting how different it is
for each viewer. For some of you it's the
elite, whoever they are.
For others, it's the Satanists. I mean,
what could be more evil than Satanists,
after all.
For other people, it's the Masons,
believe it or not, or the Alliance I've
heard recently of Jews and
Masons and Jesuits all working together
to foster a world of evil. For some
people it's the traditionalists, for
other people it's the scientists.
But, you know,
I understand that. I remember a time in
my life
when it seemed very important to take a
stand. If you don't take a stand it seems
your life
is lacking in meaning. Let me suggest
to you,
take a stand in favor of wholeness. Take
a stand in
favor of the universe, in favor of embracing
everything. Take a stand in favor of
the all-encompassing
nature of reality itself.
It's a hard thing to do sometimes.
It means loving yourself
in all of your complexity,
including loving the parts of yourself
that you're inclined to hate
and inclined to project out into the
world.
I encourage those of you who haven't
listened to the first three
videos on the “In Presence” series to take
a look at them, because it deals with these, I think of them as the
kindergarten lessons
of the “In Presence” series, one, two, and
three. They're very important.
Self-love is crucial, but in order to
truly love yourself as I point out there,
it's worth repeating,
that means loving yourself no matter
what you do, say,
think or feel. And actually, when it gets
right down to it, it means,
well, we say it this way, having warm
positive regard, which is actually
code for love for all other people, no
matter what they do,
say, think or feel; recognizing in effect
the spiritual essence
that unites us all.
I used to teach all of this in a
seminar called Omega Seminars founded by
a man named John Boyle
many decades ago. I don't believe Omega
Seminars has been active for a long time,
but back in those days when I was a
seminar leader,
people would bring up the example of
Hitler. They say, "Do I have to love Hitler
too?" And we would say, "No, that's too hard.
Don't push yourself." But actually,
yes, it includes Hitler.
I know that's a tough one for people
who think that Hitler is evil. I actually
hear from people who feel the other way
about Hitler.
There's much to be said about
the role of darkness
in the evolution of humanity.
There's also much to be said, as I
point out in one of the earlier
“In Presence” monologues, about the cosmic
game, about
getting beyond the mere human
perspective, you know, where death is
tragic and
life is good, because sometimes death
is beautiful, and sometimes life is ugly.
So, from a cosmic perspective,
even things as basic as life and death
may not look
the way they look to us, if we just
see the world through our mortal, human
eyes. I think we are cosmic beings.
We are much more than mere humans,
much more. This human garb
that we wear is sort of temporary
dressing. I mean, certainly if you take the reincarnation
research seriously,
as I do, certainly if you take
some of the research on survival after
death seriously, as I do,
certainly if you take the research on the
powers of the mind as expressed through
what we call,
and they're not the best words, but extra
sensory perception and psychokinesis.
If you take that seriously, as I do
as an empiricist, as a scientist, then you have
to look at the implications.
The implications clearly are that
the limitations of space and time
that we perceive through our bodily
senses and that seem to be the
world in which we live or the prison
in which we live or the movie
in which we live, that world
is not complete. That's a partial
description of reality,
and there is another description that we
see when we look within.
That's a cosmic reality,
maybe expressed most eloquently
by people who talk about the coming
of the cosmic Christ,
the heart of the world, the feeling of
compassion
for everything, for every sentient
creature,
for all beings on all levels.
Open your heart to that.
Let me leave you now with this question.
In your particular case, what would you
say is stopping you from opening
your heart to
everything, to all and everything, to the
wholeness
of the entire universe, in fact, to the
wholeness of all
multiverses? What prevents you from
having an
open heart as far
as infinity?
Thank you for being with me.
[Music]
